Q5VUpQnwoPA.text: [Music] hi i'm miguel delgado i'm a cosmetic and plastic surgeon i've been practicing cosmetic and plastic surgery for over 30 years i wanted to become a plastic surgeon because of the artistic component to this type of surgery i've honed my practice to become an expert in the field of cosmetic surgery in particular facelifts mommy makeovers gynecomastia and tummy tucks what's important to me in my profession in my patients is number one is top quality care and secondly is performing top quality work making my patients extremely happy my core belief is honesty integrity with my patients and choosing the proper procedure that is going to make you happy if you're happy i'm happy people undergoing plastic surgery in general are always nervous it's important for my patients to know that you can trust me i will be there beside you throughout the entire process having satisfied patients is the only thing that matters if you're not happy i'm not happy we always want our patients happy when i come into work every morning i look forward to seeing my patients seeing the result of my work and seeing a happy smiling face [Music]

OFRr-dWPJzc.text: distance yeah it's it's a really exciting time in global health and for me I always knew as a trainee looking for a place to be at and also now as a faculty that they're really only at least for me there's a couple of key institutions that did a lot of global Health work and UCSF is definitely one of them but we have a robust partnership for the Center for Health Equity and surgery and anesthesia a number of our faculty are deeply involved in that group and this can be a catalyst for people who have interest in global surgery it's a great way to kind of organize all the work that people are doing and I really feel like the way we're going about global health is in kind of this long-term sustainable collaborative way many of our residents have the chance to work abroad as well so there are opportunities for residents to travel abroad and work in Tanzania on the ground alongside residents and perform research projects there and we have a fair number of Faculty also so and we're working in different parts of the world like Tanzania Rwanda Cambodia and Peru with like longitudinal projects so as a resident I've had the chance to work with International Partners in Tanzania and Rwanda on different curriculum development projects and I've also had the chance to work with this larger organization that our faculty are involved in called the global OHS initiative that works across faculty in the U.S and abroad to help develop research projects and practice guidelines thank you [Music]

7GzUmnN1ezk.text: sleep apnea is a condition that affects millions of people around the globe it occurs when the muscles of the throat relax during sleep which can lead to blockages in air flow to the lungs and pauses in breathing each pause can last from a few seconds to over a minute and can happen many times throughout the night when this happens a lot your sleep is disrupted obstructive sleep apnea mainly occurs in the throat which includes the area from the back of the nose and mouth to the voice box the upper throat is like a flexible tube that connects the back of the nose to the windpipe the size and shape of each person's throat is unique it depends on a person's body weight the size and position of the jaw the bones of the face that support this area as well as the size of the tongue tonsils and palate the muscles that line the throat are flexible and when you are awake they are important for swallowing and talking however when you fall asleep these muscles relax if they relax to the point where the space collapses less air is able to get to the lungs and body the body senses the decreased airflow and responds by changing the depth of sleep to open the airway most people do this without waking up and may not know this is happening at night however if there are frequent pauses in breathing or large reductions in airflow during sleep your sleep quality can be affected this can lead to less refreshing sleep and daytime sleepiness even if you got a full night of rest to help you sleep better your doctor will first perform a sleep study or polysomnography to measure the severity of your sleep apnea it is a non-invasive overnight exam that monitors how many times the airflow to your body is reduced because of sleep apnea a sleep study can be done in two ways first in a facility which is called an in-lab sleep study and second at home with a kit you bring home and set up before you go to sleep the sleep study is then analyzed and each study is scored to classify sleep apnea severity into normal mild moderate or severe levels based on the ahi or apnea hippopnia index your healthcare provider can help you understand what your sleep study results mean people with moderate or severe levels of sleep apnea are at risk for high blood pressure heart disease stroke memory issues diabetes and motor vehicle accidents but there are treatments available to help with sleep apnea you
